column8: Easy Hike with a Beautiful Ella View

Little Adam‚Äôs Peak in Ella is a gentle, scenic hike offering sweeping views of emerald tea plantations, misty valleys, and distant mountains. The short trail leads to a rocky summit where sunrise and sunset paint the sky in soft hues, making it a peaceful spot for nature lovers and photographers alike.

A delightful hike to a gorgeous view point overlooking Ella Rock and beautiful nature. We've been traveling in Sri Lanka for 3 weeks and almost all sightseeing places set to charge foreigners many many times more than the locals pay. This place is free and there are some creative activities around. Highly recommended.
Very beautiful place, climbing quite comfortably, special paths and steps have been made, at the top locals will offer you refreshments. In good weather, you'll get great photos.

An easy walk and a nice view as a reward but you should not think you are there alone. It is crowded and there are many tourist attractions. In short, if you like a mountain hike you should not be here.

column8: Great views of the local landscape.
column11: A fantastic way to appreciate the views of the Sri Lankan landscape and Ella Rock. I would recommend going up to the top via the Tibetan suspended bridge/path. When at the top it is possible to go to each of the 4 other peaks. The hikes are not super challenging and not requiring particular skills. Great views and on the way back down you maybe able to get an Ayurveda massage at the 98acre SPA which is a very short walk to the right of the exit of the peak main entrance. We did not do the Zipline experience as this was very very touristy.
If you‚Äôre walking, hiking, you‚Äôve got to see it. The view is beautiful and safe. Climbing difficulty is moderate.

column8: Great view even if it's not fair to pay
column11: Beautiful place, you get there after a not too strenuous walk. The view is fantastic, the only flaw is that there is an entrance fee of 1000 rupees which for me is absolutely indecent to ask for money to access a nice view. We had an amazing time with Bentota Travel Mart who took us to Ella the service we got from them was amazing.  They took us to all the places we wanted to visit our guide was very punctual.

It took a short hour to the viewpoint and the view was absolutely fantastic. If you are in Ella this is a simple trip that gives value for money. At the first peak point they sold water and coconut-recommended. It is steep so recommend that you stay in the living room and do not go too far out to take photos.

Visiting Little Adam‚Äôs Peak was an absolutely amazing experience. The hike itself is gentle and accessible, making it perfect for anyone who enjoys a bit of adventure without it being too strenuous. As we climbed, we were surrounded by lush greenery, tea plantations, and the fresh mountain air, which made the journey incredibly refreshing. The view from the top is simply breathtaking rolling hills, valleys, and distant mountains stretch as far as the eye can see. It was the perfect spot to take a moment, soak in the scenery, and feel truly connected to nature. Our guide, Sithum, made the hike even more enjoyable. He shared interesting facts about the area, pointed out hidden viewpoints, and ensured that everyone in the group was comfortable and safe throughout the climb. Overall, Little Adam‚Äôs Peak is a must visit for anyone exploring Ella. It‚Äôs a mix of light adventure, stunning landscapes, and tranquility, and the experience will stay with you long after the hike is over.

We were expecting a slightly easier walk than it turned out to be, but it is an absolute must do when in Ella.  We walked from our homestay just outside the main street but you can get a tuk tuk for part of the way.  The walk is exposed so wear appropriate clothing or sunscreen, and take water. You will pass lots of small stalls on the way selling souvenirs at prices much cheaper than the main street but you will need small denominations to pay.  We did go on to the further peak (it's a bit of a goat track up the hill) and it is worth it for the extra views.  Good fun and took a little longer than expected. We walked from here back down an onto Nine Arches Bridge and then back into the town.

The climb of Little Adam‚Äôs Peak is definitely worth a visit! The sunrise is beautiful and offers incredible views of the surrounding mountains. Hiking is a medium difficulty: you start with a fairly simple path, then you finish with stony steps and trails, but it remains accessible if you are in good shape. Make sure you have good shoes and leave early to enjoy the freshness and the spectacle of the rising sun.
Ok nothing wow! Just another hike with spectacular views... I  would have skipped it if I knew more about it... wear comfortable shoes

Aug 2025 ‚Ä¢ Family Neutral review. Visited Aug 22nd and just about to start the climb up when there was an exodus of people descending to escape a bee swarm attack. Two women carried down fireman style by staff who literally ran down the steps. Kudos to staff, they appeared to be doing a good job evacuating, especially the two chaps who carried wounded down. One women was very badly stung and taken away by ambulance. Another half dozen walking wounded taken by truck to hospital. Returned today after the rain and had a very quiet visit. Thunderstorm an hour before meant it was virtually deserted on top. Now the ‚Äòcould do better‚Äô. Apparently drones can set bees into swarm mode. No idea if this caused yesterday‚Äôs incident, but it is a risk. There is one sign prohibiting drones, but (a) it isn‚Äôt very prominent and doesn‚Äôt say why, and (b) there is no attempt at enforcement. I had sharp words with someone about to launch today, who had no idea of the risks (probably none today after the rain, but I wasn‚Äôt taking the chance) A few more (graphic) notices about why drones are banned would raise awareness. Positive: it‚Äôs a nice view. It‚Äôs not pristine wilderness: the zip line and swing and pool bar with thumping bass will not be to everyone‚Äôs liking. But I guess these things keep general access free and provide staff cover for incidents like yesterday. Worth a visit, but if allergic to bee stings I would not risk it (same story 9-arches bridge)

Horrific experience due to a beautiful natural setting being massacred by noisy and vulgar over-tourism. They even build a "pool club" which blasts horrible disco music all accross the Valley. Stay away! Ella has been ruined by the greed of his tourism industry and local government. It's a place to run away from. Sad

We hiked little Adam‚Äôs peak with our children (11 and 16). It‚Äôs a beautiful hike - the scenery is amazing. It's a great hike and beautiful views form the top. This hike is great for a family, and there are lots of gorgeous views around. I would take some water and wear good hiking or running shoes. Amazing one day experience with SL Wayfares travel and tour team in Weligama. We reached to Ella at 9.00AM and this was our 1st hiking experience in Sri Lanka. wonderful sights and nice environment.

Not so, for once it'll go for a walk, there's one view, there's hundreds of photos of him, I don't see any point in repeating. People - crowds, souvenirs, rides, everything like any tourist hot spot.

Wonderful sunrise, beautiful views.... After we got lost at 4 am we were allowed to experience a beautiful sunrise

During my recent trip to Ella, I had the chance to hike up to Little Adam's Peak, and it was an absolutely unforgettable experience! Very good view with good people Maybe a bit too much tourists The bar was nice and the zip line was really fun I recommend this hike a lot need to see this beautiful view
At the foot are the cable car and the Ravana Pool Club with swimming pool, which unfortunately we could not visit. The climb is easy enough, the views are very picturesque!
Unfortunately we were able to see only half of the landscape due heavy fog. Nevertheless, I do recommend to visit it, but you should start ealy in the morning

Little Adam‚Äôs Peak in Ella is an absolute must-visit. I recently hiked it, and it was such a rewarding experience. The trail is well-marked and not too challenging. We spent some time taking photographs and breathing in the fresh and pure air.  From the peak you can see Ravana's cave and water falls.  Carry some water while heading to the peak.   There is a tender coconut guy  who sells passion fruit juice and tender coconut water. My favourite thing I did in Ella for me, located close to nine arches bridge and very easy to find. Point for mountain climbers and mountain scenery. Location is included in the standard package of tours. You have to climb about 500 steps to get to the top from the tuk-tuk parking lot. There is a restaurant with swimming pool and a photo swing over the mountains at the entrance

It is not an easy climb but it is definitely worth it. See all three mountains. Unless your sandals are for hiking, wear hiking shoes.

I recently hiked Ella Little Adam's Peak and had an unforgettable experience! The trail is moderately challenging, making it perfect for those who are reasonably fit but not seasoned hikers. The path is well-maintained with clear signage, and the ascent is gradual, with a few steeper sections near the top. Once you reach the summit, the panoramic views of the surrounding mountains and valleys are absolutely breathtaking. You get a great view of Ella Rock and the lush greenery of the area. Just be mindful of the sun, as it can get quite hot during midday. If you're in Ella, this hike is a must-do for nature lovers and those looking to enjoy some peace and quiet in a stunning setting. Little Adam's Peak is a must-do hike in Ella. The trail, though steep at times, offers stunning panoramic views of the surrounding hills and valleys. Little Adam‚Äôs Peak in Ella is a must-visit for breathtaking views and a relatively easy hike! The trail is well-marked, and the walk to the peak is enjoyable, with stunning scenery along the way. The start of the trailhead is easily reached walking from Ella.  The sign that says zip lining is where the trail begins.  Just pass the zip line. It's a simple climb, but it's still tiring in the heat, it was all burned on top. Expectations didn't match reality, it's better to watch dusk or dawn.

We took a tuk tuk from Ella and were glad we did. It is definitely walkable but we would have been a bit daunted having to then climb all the steps. If you go early (but after sunrise as this is very popular) then it is quiet and you can take your time. Some steps are very narrow and steep but most fitness levels should make it. It 'a trip absolutely to do because the view from above is really beautiful. The climb is not difficult at all and is affordable for everyone. If you go in a rainy period, wait until there are several leeches in the area, so before getting back in the car, check your feet carefully

A must if you are visiting Ella. We walked to the top for sunrise. You can walk from the centre or you can take a tuk tuk to the start point. We did the latter and then walked around 15 mins to the top. The walk is short but mainly up steps. Great views!

Little Adam's Peak is a popular hiking destination in Sri Lanka. Located in the Ella region, it offers stunning panoramic views of the surrounding countryside and tea plantations. The hike is relatively easy and accessible, making it suitable for a wide range of fitness levels. It gets its name from the larger Adam's Peak (Sri Pada) due to the resemblance in shape. The trail typically takes around 1 to 2 hours to complete, and the summit provides a great vantage point for photography and enjoying the natural beauty of Sri Lanka.

Nice ride. The entrance is on foot or by tuktuk to avoid a ten minute walk. Then the rather steep climb lasts 30-40 minutes, we did it with children of 3 years and 5 months in baby carrier. The view is beautiful.

The path is very easy to follow at the start, you go through some tourist attractions, carry on up some fairly significant steps and then a short trial path to the top views shown here. Wherever you may think about the tourist aspect, the views of Ella Rock are absolutely breathtaking and worth every step even though some might not see this as a 'proper' hike.

Had some lunch and a couple of beers in the garden centre near the foot of little Adam's Peak, before we started our climb. We hiked and enjoyed Adam‚Äôs view point but The restaurant at the main road ( Ella flower garden restaurant) is the worst Over rated and unprofessional
Great Walk and experience lucky to be entertained at the top with some young lads singing and dancing. Unfortunately didn't get a view as had very low cloud

I can‚Äôt say that this is something special as Little Adam‚Äôs Peak at sunrise is more of an Instagram attraction. Go there for the few IG pics and that‚Äôs it. Nice to do when in Ella, but in terms of hiking it is too short, too touristic, too simple. Basically you need to climb some stairs and in 30-40 mins you are up there with the crowd. Didn't bother going there.  Was past the zip line and just didn;t seem worth the effort.  Maybe we were being unkind.  Do your research and check if it's worth it.

Mixed feelings about this one‚Ä¶.. I would say that it is definitely a case of ‚Äúshould have been here 5 years ago‚Äù - maps show a mix of trails to L A P but these have now been gated off to steer you strictly past the super tacky and out of place pool club, cafe, zip line and rock climbing wall absolutely ruining the natural feel of an outdoor walk to a view point. Very easy hike, and wonderful view of Ella‚Äôs rock specially if you‚Äôre not into a big hike to go to Adam‚Äôs Peak. People all ages were able to climb it.

One of the favourite location in srilanka, magnificent views from the top of the Peak, less than 30 minutes will take to hike the mountain, recommended to go for the sun rise, it was very beautiful,

If you're looking for a fun and easy climbing adventure in Kandy, then Little Peaks Adam is definitely worth checking out. One of the best things about Little Peaks Adam is its location. The main entrance to the climb is only a 15-minute walk from Kandy village, making it easy to access and a great way to spend an afternoon. And once you reach the top, you'll be rewarded with panoramic views that will take your breath away. Overall, I highly recommend Little Peaks Adam for anyone looking for a fun and rewarding outdoor adventure in Kandy. The climb is easy enough for most people to enjoy, but still challenging enough to make you feel accomplished when you reach the top. And the views are simply stunning, making it an unforgettable experience.

Trek up the Little Adam‚Äôs Peak, Ella One of the prettiest spots and most popular treks in Ella is up the Little Adam‚Äôs Peak.  However, we came across an unexpected hazard. True enough that its a breathtaking view from the top of the Little Adams Peak at Ella but if you are a serious trekker challenge your self to do the real thing - the 5,500 step + tracking stretches of the Historical ADAMS PEAK that will take approx 3 - 4 hours from the base from one of the more popular access routes (Hatton - Nallathanniya / 4 hours away from Ella) Not only is it a thrilling experience with spectacular views along the way, the highlight is the sunrise from the eastern skies once you are at the peak which is absolutely breathtaking. For Sri Lankans Sri Pada assumes huge historic and religious importance and if you eventually decide to do it you will be treading along a path that was negotiated many centuries ago by historic travelers in the caliber of Buddhist traveler Fa Hien (411‚Äì12 CE) , Italian merchant / seafarer Marco Polo (1298 CE), Arab traveler Ibn Battuta (1344 CE) and in more recent history by John Davy, brother of the Sir Humphry Davy (1817 CE) The climbing season is considered to be from December to May. Off-season climbing is possible but considered more challenging and possibly best suited for seasoned trekkers. We've just got back from a holiday in Sri Lanka that, both myself and my wife agree, is the best holiday we have ever had. We were meet at the airport by Rohan from Danulanka Tours, who would be our driver, photographer and tour guide for the next two weeks. The advantage of a local driver is not to be underestimated ‚Äì as is the case in India, driving follows a set of rules that have no discernible pattern to drivers from other countries. Tolerances are measured in millimetres and cat-like reflexes are required that have been honed over many years. Rohan had an earlier career working as a photographer, which meant he was more than happy to take photographs at the various places we visited over the two weeks ‚Äì a definite improvement over the clich√©d selfie. Official tour guides in Sri Lanka are strictly controlled ‚Äì you can be sure that any official guide will have a good knowledge of the history of any historical site in Sri Lanka. The additional benefits of a tour guide is they know when you need to arrive to get the most out your visit ‚Äì whether that is to catch the ceremony at The Temple of the Tooth, or when you need to leave to get the view at World‚Äôs End, before it is obscured by cloud (5am btw, so we did a walk to Little Adam‚Äôs Peak instead). Although we had agreed a pre-defined itinerary, Rohan was more than happy to make adjustments along the way and to take into account any specific interests we had. When we commented how much better the fruit tasted in Sri Lanka than the UK, Rohan went out his way to stop en-route to pick up whatever was local to the area through which we were travelling. For example: Yellow bananas ‚Äì smaller that those in the UK, but ten times more delicious. Red bananas ‚Äì even nicer than yellow bananas. Mangos ‚Äì several different varieties. The big ones are particularly nice, and are enough for two. Yellow coconuts ‚Äì lots of milk, and then split to eat the thin white layer. Much nicer than green‚Ä¶ Jack fruits ‚Äì never heard of these before. Had the strangest consistency and taste, but definitely recommended. A drink made from a fruit that only grows in mud flats in one area of Sri Lanka ‚Äì can‚Äôt remember what it was called, but it is a must try. Cashew nuts ‚Äì also sold by the side of the road. Almost creamy in flavour. Rohan proved invaluable in other ways as well: on our Jeep safari through Yala National Park, he spotted a Leopard in a tree - something no-one else in the vehicle (including the driver) had spotted. We had several minutes watching the Leopard, before it decided to climb down ‚Äì as the most anyone else saw that day was a tail disappearing into the scrub, I am grateful for Rohan‚Äôs keen eyesight. Sadly, since the bombing earlier this year, tourists numbers are down 80% - this means Sri Lanka is currently a real bargain. You can stay in 4 and 5 star hotels, for the price of 2 or 3 star. Finally, I will say Sri Lanka is a must visit - the people are happy and friendly, and it is clean (I think even less litter that the UK). The wildlife is plentiful, even outside the wildlife parks - this is probably helped by the predominantly Buddhist culture, and the fact that farmers are compensated for any damage done by elephants. Give Sri Lanka and Danulanka Tours a go ‚Äì you will not be disappointed.

Climbing Little Adams peak was one of the activities our tour guide had organised for us whilst in Ella. Setting off early in the morning to avoid the heat we assume, it is a fairly steady walk along for a while, then a climb up some steps to the top. You do not need to be an Olympic athlete to climb this, but a certain level of fitness is required, and the last bit is quite steep; those used to walking and hiking should find it a breeze. The whole climb up and back took approx. 2 hours, but you will definitely work up a sweat doing so !  I would strongly recommend sensible footwear e.g. trainers or walking shoes, and some water ! On the way up we passed some tea pickers in the fields next to the path, who were more than happy to pose for some pictures, for a small reward / LKR tip of course ! Once at the top there is another good photo opportunity stood next to the small statue / shrine, and then some absolutely stunning views over the surrounding countryside and the valley below. There is a large rock ledge where everyone takes their turn to stand on or dangle their legs over the edge and take photos. On the way back down we passed the tea pickers again, who were now having some food - probably lunch since they start so early in the morning ?  There was also a little coconut / drinks shack hut that had opened up on the way down, where you can buy a well deserved cold drink to cool down with. A very enjoyable way to see more of the great beauty of Sri Lanka.
